questions.text: Which of the following structures is enclosed by the prevertebral fascia in the neck?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Thin layer of connective tissue that envelopes the prevertebral muscles and cervical sympathetic trunk.

Location

Anterior to the vertebral column, extending from the base of the skull to the superior mediastinum where it merges with the ligament of the vertebral column (T3/T4 level).

Extension

Axillary sheath: The cervical and brachial plexuses form from the nerves deep to the fascia, and as they extend, they pull the prevertebral fascia with them forming axillary sheath

Functions
  • Support to the vertebral column and associated muscles.
  • Compartmentalization of various cervical structures which prevents infection spread
  • Protective sheath to brachial plexus and subclavian vessels

Clinical Significance
  • Infection Spread: Particularly from the retropharyngeal space, which can lead to serious complications such as mediastinitis.

questions.text: Which of these form the scalp proper?

options.label: B
options.text: Skin and superficial fascia of the scalp

options.label: C
options.text: Skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia of the scalp

options.label: D
options.text: Skin, superficial fascia, deep fascia, and loose areolar tissue of the scalp

questions.correct_answer: C. Skin, superficial fascia, and deep fascia of the scalp

questions.text: All of the following are the contents of the occipital triangle of the neck except?
questions.explanation:
Boundaries
  • Anterior: Posterior border of sternocleidomastoid
  • Posterior: Anterior border of trapezius
  • Base: Middle one-third of clavicle

Division

(by the inferior belly of omohyoid)
  • Occipital part-larger upper part
  • Supraclavicular part or Subclavian part-smaller lower part

Division

Nerves

Vessels

Lymph Nodes

Occipital Triangle
  • Spinal accessory nerve (CN XI)
  • Cutaneous branches of cervical plexus:
    • Lesser occipital nerve
    • Great auricular nerve
    • Anterior cutaneous nerve of neck
    • Supraclavicular nerves
  • Muscular branches:
    • To levator scapulae
    • To trapezius
    • To rhomboids
  • Transverse cervical artery and vein
  • Occipital artery
  • Occipital nodes
  • Supraclavicular nodes

Subclavian Triangle
  • Roots and trunks of brachial plexus
  • Nerve to serratus anterior (long thoracic nerve)
  • Nerve to subclavius
  • Suprascapular nerve
  • Subclavian artery and vein
  • Suprascapular artery and vein
  • Transverse cervical artery and termination of the corresponding vein
  • External jugular vein

A few members of the supraclavicular chain

questions.text: Choose the appropriate set of correct statement(s) regarding the triangle shown in the image below (red-shaded region) 1) bounded posteroinferiorly by posterior belly of digastric 2) Floor of the triangle is formed by hyoglossus anteriorly 3) Submental artery runs through anterior part of triangle 4) Carotid artery runs through posterior part of triangle
questions.explanation:
Description:
  • Also known as submandibular triangle
  • Enclosed between two bellies of digastric muscle

Attachments:

Anteroinferiorly

Anterior belly of the digastric muscle

Posteroinferiorly

Posterior belly of the digastric muscle (Statement 1) and stylohyoid muscle

Base

Base of the mandible, with an imaginary line from the mandible angle to the mastoid process

Apex

Intermediate tendon of the digastric muscle

Floor:

Anteriorly

Mylohyoid (Statement 2)

Posteriorly

Hyoglossus

Roof:
  • Investing layer of deep cervical fascia: Encloses submandibular lymph nodes
  • Superficial fascia: Platysma, cervical branch of facial nerve, ascending branch of transverse cervical nerve

Contents:

Anterior part
  • Submandibular salivary gland
  • Submandibular lymph nodes
  • Hypoglossal nerve
  • Facial vein (superficial to gland)
  • Facial artery (deep to gland)
  • Submental artery (Statement 3)
  • Mylohyoid nerve and vessels


 

Posterior part
  • External carotid artery (Statement 4)
  • Carotid sheath and contents: Internal carotid artery, internal jugular vein, vagus nerve
  • Structures passing between the external and internal carotid arteries: Styloglossus, stylopharyngeus, glossopharyngeal nerve, styloid process

questions.text: You notice the following examination being done in ED, all of the following are boundaries of the space containing the palpated structure except
questions.explanation:
Boundaries
  • Anterosuperior: Posterior belly of digastric (vs Option A); Stylohyoid (Option B)
  • Anteroinferior: Superior belly of omohyoid (Option C)
  • Posterior: Anterior border of sternocleidomastoid (Option D)

Floor:
  • Thyrohyoid
  • Hyoglossus
  • Middle constrictor
  • Inferior constrictor

Contents
  • Carotid arteries: Common carotid artery, Internal carotid artery, External carotid artery and its first five branches (superior thyroid, lingual, facial, ascending pharyngeal and occipital)
  • Carotid sinus and carotid body
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Last three cranial nerves: Vagus nerve, Spinal accessory nerve, Hypoglossal nerve
  • Carotid sheath
  • Ansa cervicalis
  • Cervical part of the sympathetic chain
  • Deep cervical lymph nodes

questions.text: During thyroid surgery, the surgeon retracts the muscles forming the floor of the muscular triangle of neck to access the thyroid gland. Which of the following muscles does he not retract?
questions.explanation:
Location
  • In the anterior region of the neck

Boundaries
  • Anterior: Midline of the neck (from hyoid bone to suprasternal notch)
  • Anterosuperior: Superior belly of the omohyoid muscle
  • Posteroinferior: Anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid muscle

Floor
  • Sternothyroid, sternohyoid, and thyrohyoid muscles

Roof
  • Investing layer: Deep cervical fascia
  • Superficial fascia: Contains the anterior jugular vein and lymph nodes

Contents
  • Infrahyoid muscles: Sternohyoid & Omohyoid (superficial) and Sternothyroid & Thyrohyoid (deep) (Option C)
  • Deeper structures: Thyroid gland, trachea, and esophagus

questions.text: Image below shows a method of brachial plexus block. Identify the correct set of approaches and the corresponding space in the neck.
questions.explanation:
Brachial plexus block:

Approaches

Interscalene approach:

  • Difficult to perform
  • Landmark: Transverse process of C6 vertebra
  • Relatively less safe

 

Indication

Emergency and elective surgery of the upper extremity

questions.text: You notice the following procedure being done in OT. Choose the appropriate set of incorrect statement(s) regarding the same. 1) Congenital long QT syndrome is an indication in children 2) Can be done to manage Hyperhidrosis and Raynaud’s phenomenon 3) Local anaesthetic is injected superior to longus colli muscle 4) Relatively unsafe procedure 5) Contralateral Horner syndrome is verification for correct placement of block
questions.explanation:
Indications
  • Children: Congenital long QT syndrome, pain syndromes (eg. herpes zoster ophthalmicus) (Statement 1)
  • Adults: Hyperhidrosis, Raynaud’s phenomenon (Statement 2)

Procedure
  • Local anesthetic is injected superior to longus colli muscle. (Statement 3)
  • Cervicothoracic (stellate) sympathetic block is identified via USG-guided probe and block given.

Verification
  • Ipsilateral Horner syndrome is seen after correct placement of block (vs Statement 5)

Complications
  • Injury to vital vascular structures in proximity (carotid artery, internal jugular vein)
  • Neural puncture (recurrent laryngeal nerve, vagus nerve)
  • Injury to thyroid gland/esophagus/trachea
  • Pneumothorax

questions.text: Patient presented with a painful swelling as shown below. Senior doctor says the pain is due to the underlying fascia. All of the following structures are enclosed by the layer forming this fascia except
questions.explanation:
Location
  • Lies deep to the platysma, encircling the neck like a collar
  • Forms the roof of the posterior triangle of the neck

Superior Attachments
  • External occipital protuberance
  • Superior nuchal line
  • Mastoid process, styloid process
  • External acoustic meatus
  • Base of the mandible

Inferior Attachments

Spine of scapula

Posterior Attachments
  • Ligamentum nuchae
  • Spine of seventh cervical vertebra (C7)

Anterior Attachments
  • Symphysis menti
  • Hyoid bone

Enclosed Structures
  • Muscles: Trapezius (Option B), Sternocleidomastoid
  • Salivary glands: Parotid, Submandibular gland (Option C)

  • Spaces:
    • Suprasternal space of Burns: Sternal heads of bilateral sternocleidomastoid; Jugular venous arch; Interclavicular ligament
    • Supraclavicular space: External jugular vein (Option D) ; Supraclavicular nerves
  • Forms pulleys for digastric and omohyoid tendons
  • Forms roof of anterior and posterior triangles
  • Forms stylomandibular ligament (separates parotid gland from the submandibular gland) and parotido-masseteric fascia

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a function of the pretracheal fascia?

options.label: D
options.text: Limiting the spread of infection in the anterior neck

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe neck pain, difficulty swallowing, and fever. A CT scan reveals a deep neck infection that has spread into the mediastinum. Which anatomical space is most likely involved in this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Submental space
  • Deep to upper investing layer of deep cervical fascia, superficial to mylohyoid muscles

Submandibular space
  • Deep to the concerned half of the mandible, between the anterior and posterior bellies of the digastric muscle

Sublingual space
  • Deep to mylohyoid muscles in the floor of the mouth, continuous with the opposite side

Peritonsillar space
  • Part of intrapharyngeal space, around palatine tonsils between pillars of fauces

Parapharyngeal space
  • On either side of the posterolateral aspect of pharynx
  • Medially - superior constrictor of pharynx
  • Laterally - medial pterygoid

Retropharyngeal space
  • Anteriorly - buccopharyngeal fascia of pharynx
  • Posteriorly - prevertebral layer
  • Laterally - carotid sheath
  • Superiorly - cranial base

Pretracheal space
  • Behind pretracheal fascia and infrahyoid muscles, in front of the anterior wall of esophagus.

Retrovisceral space
  • Between the posterior wall of pharynx/esophagus and prevertebral fascia.

Prevertebral space
  • Between prevertebral fascia and vertebral column.

Carotid space
  • Around the contents of carotid sheath, demarcated by parts of investing, pretracheal, and prevertebral layers.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not the content of carotid sheath?
questions.explanation:
Contents
  • Common carotid artery
  • Internal carotid artery
  • Internal jugular vein
  • Vagus nerve.

Anatomical Details
  • The carotid sheath extends from the upper border of the thyroid cartilage down to the bifurcation of the carotid arteries.
  • The internal jugular vein is lateral to the carotid artery; the vagus nerve is located between and posterior to the vessels.

Anteriorly

The carotid sheath is covered by the pretracheal fascia.

Posteriorly

The carotid sheath is bordered by the prevertebral fascia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about parotid gland is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The parotid duct passes through the masseter muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: The parotid gland is innervated by the facial nerve (CN VII).

options.label: C
options.text: The parotid gland is located anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle.

options.label: D
options.text: The parotid gland primarily secretes mucous saliva.

questions.correct_answer: A. The parotid duct passes through the masseter muscle.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is scheduled for a parotidectomy due to a tumor in the parotid gland. The surgeon reviews the anatomical relationships to avoid damage to surrounding structures. Which of the following structures is located superiorly to the parotid gland?
questions.explanation:
Anteriorly
  • Masseter muscle
  • Buccal fat pad

Posteriorly
  • External ear
  • Mastoid process
  • Sternocleidomastoid muscle

Medially
  • Styloid process and associated muscles (styloglossus, stylohyoid, digastric)
  • Carotid artery and internal jugular vein
  • Cranial nerves IX (glossopharyngeal), X (vagus), and XI (accessory)
  • Mandibles ramus

Laterally

Skin and superficial fascia

Inferiorly
  • Angle of the mandible
  • Submandibular gland

Superiorly

Zygomatic arch

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the structures within the parotid gland are accurate? The external carotid artery enters the parotid gland through the posteromedial surface. The maxillary artery exits through the posterior surface of the gland. The superficial temporal artery branches into the transverse facial artery and emerges from the anterior part of the superior surface. The superficial temporal vein and maxillary vein unite to form the retromandibular vein, which divides into anterior and posterior divisions near the apex of the gland. The facial nerve enters the parotid gland and passes behind the retromandibular vein.
questions.explanation:
Structures Within the Parotid Gland

Arteries

 
  • External Carotid Artery: Enters through the posteromedial surface.
  • Maxillary Artery: Exits through the anteromedial surface.
  • Superficial Temporal Artery: Branches into the transverse facial artery and emerges from the anterior part of the superior surface.

Veins

 
  • Superficial Temporal Vein and Maxillary Vein unite to form the Retromandibular Vein, which divides into anterior and posterior divisions near the apex of the gland.

Facial Nerve
  • Exits the skull through the Stylomastoid Foramen, enters the parotid gland at the posteromedial surface, passing in front of the retromandibular vein and external carotid artery.
  • Divides into Temporofacial and Cervicofacial branches near the neck of the mandible, further branching into five terminal branches: Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Marginal Mandibular, and Cervical, exiting along the anterior border and apex of the gland.

Lymphatics
  • Contains parotid lymph nodes located in the superficial fascia and deep to the deep fascia over the gland.

Parotid Duct/ Stensen's Duct
  • About 5 cm long.
  • Origin: Emerges from the middle of the parotid gland's anterior border.
  • Course: Runs forward over the masseter muscle, then makes a medial turn at the masseter's anterior border.
  • Structures Pierced:
    • Buccal Pad of Fat
    • Buccopharyngeal Fascia
    • Buccinator Muscle (penetrates obliquely)
  • Termination: After passing through the buccinator, the duct travels briefly between the buccinator and oral mucosa, then opens into the vestibule of the mouth opposite the upper second molar's crown.
  • This oblique passage prevents the duct from inflating with air when blowing.
